adjectives.description: slipper (comparative more slipper, superlative most slipper)

entries.meaning: A low soft shoe that can be slipped on and off easily.
Such a shoe intended for indoor use; a bedroom or house slipper.
examples: Get out of bed, put on your slippers, and come downstairs.

entries.meaning: (US, Hawaii, Singapore) A flip-flop (type of rubber sandal).

examples: Virtually all human action is liable to opposing interpretations, depending mainly upon distance: to take the familiar case of the banana peel, the fall is painful to the slipper, hilarious to the spectator across the street.

entries.meaning: A kind of apron or pinafore for children.
A kind of brake or shoe for a wagon wheel.
(engineering) A piece, usually a plate, applied to a sliding piece, to receive wear and permit adjustment; a gib.
A form of corporal punishment where the buttocks are repeatedly struck with a plimsoll; "the slipper".
examples: "Mrs Marlene Foster  […] , an opponent of the slipper, said her son Gary had a bottom "as red as a beetroot" after he was punished for writing on desks. "

entries.meaning: (euphemistic) The plimsoll or gym shoe used in this form of punishment.
examples: "All teachers had what was referred to as a 'slipper', but in reality was a cut down gym shoe designed for smacking our bottoms."

entries.meaning: (medicine) A kind of bedpan urinal shaped like a shoe.

verbs.description: slipper (third-person singular simple present slippers, present participle slippering, simple past and past participle slippered)

entries.meaning: (UK, Australia, New Zealand) To spank with a plimsoll as corporal punishment.
examples: "One boy was slippered five times in four days for offences such as missing detention, fooling about and being out of bounds."
